document.text: Yearly audios by a member of the state auditing board were approved Monday by the Appomattox Mayor and Town Council. The town fathers had considered a bi-annual audit system to possibly save money, but Town Manager Bill Britton said a representative of the state board, told him there would be minimal if any savings to the town if an audit was taken every other year. Having the state audit toe towns books wul save some money, according to B ritton. The audit will cost appoximately 4,500 yearly, or about 15 per hour for 900 man hours of work. The audit would cost considerably more if done by a CPA, according to . Britton. In another m atter, council members referred to the water committee a plan to take over a weU currently serving the Walton Piaee subdivision outside of town.  The well, owned by BiU Jameraon, meets state water quality standards and would be a suitable water source for the town. The proposal would involve the towns taking over the weU and water system at no charge, and continuing to service the W alton Place w ater customers. . Laying water lines to connect the weU with the towns system would cost in the neighborhood of 28,000 for labor according to B ritten and approximately tl4j000 for 4,200 feet-of fine. The proposal will be considered for review and comment by the towns water rmandlton. , In eth er business, the council

Biitton, Jr., Appomat tox town marfager, is meeting this week with representatives of Technological Research, Inc., a subsidiary of Campbell Soup Company, Inc., and the State W ater Control Board in Richntpnd to discuss the possibility and feasibility of an over-land flow sewer treatm ent facility for the Town of Appomattox.  The meeting follows a trip to Chestertown, Md., last week by various town officials to view a similar system in operation there. Going on the trip to Maryland were Britton, Mayor Ronald giggle, Councilmen Bob. Hubbard and Maurice Gordon, past Major Henry Pack, and townsewer operator John H arris, as well as representatives from Amelia County Board of Supervisor, three members of Chase City Town Council, two representa tives fax, the health depart- meoWanda consulting engineer for the tdvn,. In Chestertown last Thurs day, according to Britton, the group saw a- 20-year-old working over-land flow and line saturation system with solids removecPprior to land applica tion. rad without ray enter- gen cy holding facility. The system operates 100- percent of the time due to the lack of holding facilities, which were not required at the time of installation,  . The twp representatives from the Virginia State Health Department, according o Brit ton, made comments that in Virginia, in accordance with the existing regulatkms, the pre- treatment of solids and the holding ponds would be mandatory for the system to be installed. Britton looked at a one-year- old system in Easley, S. C. in November of last year that was working perfectly with the exception of a few design problem s. The 20-year-old system in Maryland is meeting the requirem ents of the Maryland State Water Control Board, but aa viewed by the delegation from here, could be run more efficiently. document.text: Wounded in the gun battle and charged with the crime is Frank Mayberry, 47 of Evergreen. It appears that Tucker was slain on the back porch of the residence in Evergreen in which he and his wife, her mother, and her brother, May berry lived. This shooting apparently occurred sometime after 10 oclock Friday night. Called to the scene from his home in Appomattox, Dr. Christian was on an errand of mercy. From a re construction of the events, it appears that the popular young doctor was shot as he approached the door of the -house. Christians body was found on the walk to the house, and removed only after a terriffic gun battle between the posse and Mayberry. Nearly two hours passed between the shooting of Tucker and the flni arrest, of May- berry- Mayberry was Yelled by a shotgun blast near a garage hide out from which he had fired from 30 to 50 shots from a pistol and a shotgun at the surrounding officers. Mayberry was given medical treat ment here and sent to Rlctnond Saturday morning. His wounds are said not to be serious. The midnight sounding of sirens and the use oi flares to light up the scene attracted the attention of a sizeable gathering of spectators and details of the tragedy have been the topic of interest here since. Funeral services for the victims were held Monday. Serviced for Mr. Tucker were conducted from the Evergreen Baptist Chunch, by the pastor, the Rev. D. L. Bailey. Mili tary services were conducted by the grave by American Legion Post 104. Burial was in the Evergreen Ceme tery. Funeral services for Dr.Christlan were held here Monday at 11 A. M., from Appomattox Court House Pres byterian Church, conducted by his pastor, Dr. Twyman Williams, as sisted by Dr. C. A. Collins, Jr., and the Rev. B. T. Price. A great concourse of friends gath ered for the services. An outpour ing of floral tributes and messages of condolence bore testimony to the esteem in which th1 young physician and his family are held. Son of Dr. D. A. Christian, Jr. the physician began his practice here following service in the Navy during World War II. He occupied the office his father had used for a generation of service to the people of this area. Affectionay known as Young Doctor David, he endeared himself to the public by his skill as a physician and the charm of his personality. He was serving as a member of the Appo mattox Town Council and recently organized a group here to further the cause of physical education at the Appomattox school. As a mark of respect, local busi ness places closed during the funeral hour. A movement has begun to have an appropriate memorial in his hon or. A meeting of friends was held this week to organize a memorial movement, and another meeting will be held Monday night. Dr. Christian is survived .by his wife, the former Louise Campbell of Staunton three children, Mary, 6 Pamela, 4, and David A. Christ ian, IV, 7 months his father, Dr. David A. Christian, Jr and the fol lowing sisters and brother Mrs. George L. Koos, of Tangent, Ore- - gon Mrs. Worth Harris, La Crosse, Florida Mrs. Harold E. Thompson, Jr. Staten Island, New York Mrs. W. J. document.text: With nearly every eligile voter casting a ballot Tuesday, citizens of the Town of Appomattox named ane automobile dealer, Charles T. Mioses, Jr., as Mayor and another automobile dealer, John S. Ginels as top winner for the six-member Town Council. The Times-Virginian unofficial talley sheet showed Moses ahead, by a dose margin of 220 votes for Mayor to 216 for incumbent Richard D. Robinson. This was the closest race for Mayor here in many years. The ally sheet showed the fol lowing results for Council, with, the top six elected John S. G rin d s ....................... 280 C, Lewis McDeanmon ........... 266 John C, Caldwell . . . . . . . . 261 Grover E. Smith 230 T. Hunter Dickerson . . . . 2215 Clarence C. Poe ................... 269 Mrs. Calvin Roibineon . . . . 206 Ivey Holland ....................... 169 Grover P. Beasley Jr .............. 139 B. H. Guill ........................... 120 J, T. Almond ....................... 11.0 S. J. Evans .......................  . 109 J. T. Irby ................................ 95 The new town officials will take office in September, and serve for a term of two years. The Mayor-elect, Charles Thomas Closes, Jr., is the son of State Sen ator and Mrs. Ohas. T. Moses, of Appomattox. He was born in Appo mattox in August of 1922. He grad uated from Appomattox High School in 1946 and entered Virginia Mili tary Institute in that fall, where he studied until May 1943, when he entered the United States Army as a private. A red letter day in bis life was May 22, 1943, the day on which he received hie War Diploma from Vir ginia Military Institute enlisted .in the U. S. Army and was married to Mies Ruby Martin, the daughter of Mrs. E, B. Martin and the late Mr. Martin, of Oakville. While in the Army, he attained the rank of First Lieutenant in the Combat Engineers. After serving approximately 3 yearn in the mili tary service, inchidingbatii the European and Pacific Theaters, he returned to Appomattox, where he began his business career with the Moses Motor Company, he Chevro let and Oldsmobile Dealership own ed and operated by his father and grandfather, C. T. and T. W. Moses. Charles Thomas and Ruby are the proud parents of three daughters, Joan, Janet and Linda Jo, and an infant son, Charles Thomas, HI, All of the Moses family are mem bers of Memorial Methodist Church, where Charles IteomaD it  member of he Official Board  Charge Lay Leader and a Sunday School teach er. Since his return to Appomattox in 1646, he has been very much in terested -in the .civic affairs of the community. He  helped organize the National Guard Unit at Appomattox and served as its Commanding Of ficer for three years. He has been quite active in the American Le gion, having served aa Commander of the Post 164 for two years, has served as Fourth District Oratorical Chairman for the Legion Depart ment of Virginia, and is a member of the 46  8 Voiture 1133. He is a member and Past Presi dent of the Appomattox Parent- Teacher Association, and is a mem ber of the Appomattox Lions Club. He is a member of the Board of Directors of the Farmers National Bank, and previously served for 3 terms as a member of the Town Council.

In June of1979, the Town of Appomattox received a 1.4 million grant from the Environ mental Protection Agency EPA and the State Water Control Board for a new regional wastewater facility. EPA and the State Water Control Board had mandated to the Town of Appomattox that they build a pew regional wastewater facility. In addition to the grant, the town wifi have to come up with 2500,000, 25 percent of the total cost of the facility. Council decided to hold a referendum in mid-August to let the citizens decide on this question- However, the -refer endum had to be abandoned in August when the town was notified that a Special Election set for Sept. 4 was not permissabie under the State Statutes concerning Special Elections. The wily possible date would be Nov. 6 in the General Election and the deadline for the grant apphe tion was Sept. 30. document.text: volunteer services. Mrs. Helen McCraw and Wallace Clair have been ap pointed by the Appomattox County Board of Supervisors to represent our county. In Appomattox County there are 1,584 persons aged 60 and over. Clair further reported to the council that an emergency fuel service is available to the elderly who qualify. There is 2,600 in the fund but so far there have been no applications for help in this area from our county. Any person 60 or older who qualifies can get emergen cy fuel free or be given the opportunity to repay either part or all of the fuel bill if they so choose. In other business before council, Mrs. Jeanne Stanley, owner of Jeannep Steak House, and J. T. Guill, owner of Guills Restaurant, asked council for permission to sell beer and wine on Sundays from the hours of 1 p.m. to 7 p.m. Mrs. Stanley asked to be allowed to sell on premises only and Guill asked to be allowed to sell off premises. No action was taken at this meeting but a decision is to be made prior to the next meeting of the Town Council. Council voted to authorize the Property Committee to get bids from Lawson Ford, Inc.

document.text: Town taxes in Appomattox were cut from 6Qc per 100 valuation to 50c, at the regular monthly meeting of the town council here Monday night of this week, by unanimous vote. This will cut about 500 from the revenue of the town this year. - . Last year the council reduc ed the town tax from 7.5c to 60c and the cut this week means that the town revenue has been cut one-third in two years. This years cut wilFap- ply on 1933 taxes. That the max imum speed limit on Lee - Grant Avenue shall be 15 miles per hour 25 miles per hour on Court Street, and 15 miles per hour on Church Street and Main Street. All limits to become effective and enforced upon erection of proper signs and publication. i TOWN COUNCIL 1 Dated September 5, 1949.

document.text: Town of Appomattox voters will elect a Mayor and six members of the Town Gopncil in a regular elec tion to be held June 11. Those elec ted will serve two-year terms. The deadline. for filing is sixty days before the election, which gives prospective candidates several weeks yet. . However, three have already filed. They are For Miayor Frank M. McCann, local attorney, filed on Feb. 15. F-or Town Council J. C. Cald well filed on Jan. 31. J. T. Irby filed Feb. 20. Both Caldwell and Irby are in cumbent counoilmen. Other incum bent members of council are M ts . Calvin Robinson, council president and Grover Smith, W. S. Gills and T. Hunter Dickerson, The incumbent Mayor, Richard D. Robinson, has not announced whether he would be a candidate. He is serving out the unexpired term of Ohas. F. James, who was elected Mayor two years ago.
